Comment:
This is a game that I should have won, but lost because I underestimated the strength of a knight against a rook

Reti opening - I don't know much about this so I looked in the opening database and made a move that leaves it up to white to start with
The main lines convert to a QP game by d4 or c4. I decided to go for a line that would go for e5 and then f5 by black

17.Bxd5 Nxd5 and there are lots of threats including f3 and Qh3, e4 with a discovered attack on the rook and then e3 or Nc3. The rook on the b file can also switch quickly to the king side. If white leaves the knight on f1 with a black knight on d5 it is hard to defend g2
This is very strong but unfortunately black cannot quite force mate and white ecspes at the cost of some material

19. Kg1 Qh3 20. Ne6 Nd5 and white can only avoid mate by sacrificing the Q. Now the rook can protect g2 and try as I might I could not find a mating variation
If 20. Rb1 Qh3 21. Ne6 Nd5 22. Rg1 Nc3 wins rook for knight at least, with lots of other possibilities
If 20. Rb1 Qh3 21. Ne6 Nd5 22. Rg1 Nc3 wins rook for knight at least, with lots of other possibilities

Here I said to myself that I was material up, could take the d pawn and swap queens, and then it would be plain sailing. What I should have done is looked at how weak my pawns were and kept the pressure on while I improved the position by swapping some of them off. White is very tied down by the need to defend the g2 square and by advancing the h pawn I could have brought the rooks into play. h5, Rf7, Ng6 would have been better, and thye queen swap would have been much better if the g4 square was not avaialble to the knight

Big mistake.... h5 would have been better, followed by Nd6 and h4. Once the h file is open white is in trouble, and the f and c pawns can be defended long enough to press the attack

25 Rc2 was a trap because of 25....Nf5 26. Rc1 Nxe3 27. fxe3 Rxe3 and the two central passed pawns will soon win. However in setting this trap I failed to notice Ng4!

threatening multiple forks. All my pieces are on the wrong squares, which is what you should think about before forcing a queen swap!

In theory I am still a pawn to the good and I still thought I was winning. But wherever I wanted to put my rooks the knight keeps harrassing them and in a few moves I am going to lose either the h pawn or the c pawn
